content.user_title: Integrate MCP servers into Claude Code plugins
content.value_statement: You need a clear way to connect external tools and services to your plugin. This skill shows safe MCP configuration, authentication, and tool usage patterns.
actual_capabilities: Explain how to configure MCP servers in .mcp.json or plugin.json.
Describe stdio, SSE, HTTP, and WebSocket MCP server types.
Show MCP tool naming and allowed-tools frontmatter usage.
Detail OAuth, token, and environment variable authentication patterns.
Provide examples for server configuration and tool usage.
limitations: Requires a running MCP server or local executable to function.
Configuration changes require a Claude Code restart.
OAuth works only for MCP servers that implement OAuth.
This skill does not ship server binaries.

use_cases.title: Add tool access to a plugin
use_cases.description: Set up MCP servers and expose external tools inside Claude Code commands.

use_cases.title: Connect hosted services
use_cases.description: Configure SSE or HTTP MCP servers with secure headers and tokens.

use_cases.title: Standardize MCP patterns
use_cases.description: Document authentication, tool naming, and error handling for consistent plugins.

prompt_templates.title: Beginner setup
prompt_templates.scenario: Create a simple MCP config file
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a .mcp.json example for a local filesystem server using stdio and an allowed path. Include a brief note about env variables.

prompt_templates.title: OAuth integration
prompt_templates.scenario: Use a hosted SSE MCP server
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to configure an SSE MCP server for a hosted service with OAuth and explain the user authentication flow.

prompt_templates.title: Token auth
prompt_templates.prompt: Provide an HTTP MCP configuration using bearer tokens from environment variables and list required variables.

prompt_templates.title: Advanced workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Design a plugin MCP setup with two servers, one stdio and one SSE, and describe tool naming and allowed-tools usage.

output_examples.input: Explain how to connect a hosted MCP server and allow its tools in a command.
output: Use an SSE MCP entry with a secure HTTPS URL.
Restart Claude Code so the server is discovered.
Add specific mcp__plugin_... tool names to allowed-tools in the command.

best_practices: Use HTTPS or WSS endpoints and environment variables for secrets.
Pre-allow only required MCP tools in commands.
Document required variables and OAuth scopes in README.
anti_patterns: Hardcoding tokens or credentials in configuration.
Using wildcard allowed-tools without a strong need.
Using insecure HTTP or WS endpoints.

faq.question: Is this compatible with Claude Code plugins?
faq.answer: Yes, it targets Claude Code plugin MCP configuration and tool usage.

faq.question: What limits should I expect?
faq.answer: You must run or host MCP servers, and configuration changes need a restart.

faq.question: How do I integrate multiple servers?
faq.answer: Add multiple entries in .mcp.json with distinct server names and types.

faq.question: Is my data safe?
faq.answer: Use HTTPS or WSS and store tokens in environment variables, not files.

faq.question: What if tools do not appear?
faq.answer: Check /mcp, validate config, and restart Claude Code after changes.

faq.question: How does this compare to inline plugin.json?
faq.answer: A dedicated .mcp.json is clearer for multiple servers and easier to maintain.
